title: 114_s2217
content: The Act titled "Common Sense Nutrition Disclosure Act of 2015" amends disclosure requirements for restaurants and similar retail food establishments. The Act "Common Sense Nutrition Disclosure Act of 2015" amends Section 403(q)(5)(H) of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act to update calorie disclosure requirements for standard menu items in restaurants and retail food establishments. The Act "Common Sense Nutrition Disclosure Act of 2015" updates calorie disclosure requirements for standard menu items in restaurants and retail food establishments by specifying the number of calories per serving or per common unit division of the item. The Act "Common Sense Nutrition Disclosure Act of 2015" updates calorie disclosure requirements for standard menu items in restaurants and retail food establishments by specifying the number of calories per serving or common unit division. The information can be provided through a remote-access menu as the sole method of disclosure. The Act "Common Sense Nutrition Disclosure Act of 2015" updates calorie disclosure requirements for standard menu items in restaurants and retail food establishments by specifying the number of calories per serving or common unit division. The Secretary shall establish standards for menu variability and combination meals through regulation. The Secretary will set standards for determining and disclosing nutrient content for menu items with different flavors or varieties, allowing flexibility for restaurants to choose how to disclose the information. Methods may include using ranges for disclosure. The Secretary may allow various methods for determining and disclosing nutrient content for menu items, including ranges, averages, individual labeling, or a preset standard build. The Secretary must issue proposed regulations within one year of the Common Sense Nutrition Disclosure Act of 2015 enactment. The Common Sense Nutrition Disclosure Act of 2015 requires final regulations to not take effect earlier than 2 years after promulgation. Restaurants are not mandated to provide certifications for menu items. The Common Sense Nutrition Disclosure Act of 2015 requires final regulations to not take effect earlier than 2 years after promulgation. Restaurants are not mandated to provide certifications for menu items, including definitions related to menus and menu boards. The term 'preset standard build' refers to the finished version of a menu item commonly ordered by consumers, while 'standard menu item' is a food item prepared in the same way with the same components, routinely offered at 20 or more locations under the same name. The Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act is amended to provide restaurants with 90 days to correct violations before any enforcement action is taken. Additionally, exemptions from certain subsections are clarified for national uniformity. Section 403(q)(5)(H) of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act is further amended to include a limitation on liability for restaurants or similar retail food establishments regarding civil actions in Federal or State court for claims arising from violations of nutrition labeling requirements.
